title: Getting started with RStudio (Safari Books Online)
description: RStudio is the R user's Integrated Development Environment (IDE) of choice, there is no doubt about that. Installing it is really straightforward, just go to http://www.rstudio.org/download/ and download your OS version. If you need more information, this freely available book chapter by Safari Books Online gives a really thorough introduction into what RStudio actually is, why you should use it, and how it integrates with R.

title: Try R (CodeSchool)
description: CodeSchool offers a free course for learning R that let's you solve little quizzes in an interactive shell. I especially like the fact that your inputs are actually evaluated in a real R environment, so you can playfully try out just about anything. In this course, the focus lies on "native" methods and packages, i.e., you'll learn the very basics of R without going into other, higher-level packages such as dplyr.

title: R Programming (Coursera)
description:
This course, which is part of the Coursera Data Science Specialization, features instruction videos and requires you to solve quizzes and complete programming assignments. The first part of the course (first two weeks) focuses on basic R data types and programming concepts, while the second part (week 3 and 4) goes into more advanced concepts such as debugging and profiling, which might be a bit overkill for you (which is why I set the level to "Intermediate").

Nonetheless, participating will reward you greatly as the course really forces you to not just listen but also program stuff on your own. By the way: The Data Science Specialization makes use of R in all of its courses, so there might be some other interesting stuff to learn waiting for you.

title: R Programming (Swirl)
description: Swirl is another great way to interactively learn the basics of R. It runs from within R and is installed just like any other R package. There exists a range of Swirl courses which cover different aspects of the data journalism process. For getting started, the "R Programming" course is recommended (it somehow follows the first part of the corresponding Coursera course, and Swirl was actually created with the help of that course's authors). Hack away!

title: Cookbook for R
description: "Cookbook for R" is a problem-solution-style, free e-book. For learning the basics of R, I would recommend trying out chapters 1 through 5. Apart from that, I often use it to look up quick recipes for working with ggplot2 (chapter 8).

title: Scraping HTML tables with XML
description: In this short tutorial, it is shown how the XML package and its nifty readHTMLTable() function can be used to download and parse a rather large table of MPs' expenses in the UK. Piece of cake!

title: Scraping static web pages with rvest
description:
A rather new package developed by Hadley Wickham makes scraping and parsing of static HTML really easy. Instead of having to loop through countless levels of HTML/XML code as you would with the XML package, you can query data by using good ol' CSS selectors – wait, you're not a CSS ninja? There's a handy helper for that, too.

rvest, like most packages by Hadley, makes use of magrittr sytax, which greatly improves the readability and maintainability of your code.

title: Using R to download and parse JSON: an example using data from an open data portal
description: This well-structured tutorial uses the RJSONIO package to download and parse JSON from a website. It makes extensive use of sapply and, thus, functional programming to navigate through the hierarchy of the downloaded JSON, so you should be at least a bit familiar with these concepts. In the end, the parsed data are used to build a nice little map using the popular rgdal and ggplot2 packages.

title: Scraping dynamic web pages with RSelenium
description:
Scraping static web content such as tables and the like is pretty straightforward. However, when content is dynamically loaded via Javascript/AJAX, packages such as XML or rvest won't bring you far. RSelenium is an R binding for Selenium, which itself is actually a test framework for web applications. Using RSelenium it is possible to programmatically navigate a web browser, execute Javascript code, and wait for the content you need to load – which can then be downloaded and further processed in R.

As far as I know, there currently exists no tutorial on using RSelenium explicitly for scraping, but this vignette and this webinar might help you get started.

title: Scraping Javascript generated data with R
description:
In this blog post, the guys from DataCamp want to scrape HTML tables from a website. The problem is that these tables are only loaded and generated via Javascript, and not statically. In order to get the data nonetheless, they call an external Javascript file and execute it via PhantomJS, which is basically a WebKit browser without a graphical user interface. The Javascript file loads the website and writes its content into a static HTML file. The rest is done in R: The local HTML file is parsed with the well-known rvest and with the help of some regular expressions.

I guess the tl;dr of this tutorial is that you can call external scripts from within R using the system() function – no need to use RSelenium in this case.

title: Data tidying
description: One can consider this and the associated journal paper the Holy Bible of data janitors. In this vignette, Hadley Wickham introduces a way of how data should be structured and formatted in order to be properly analyzed. For tidying messy data, he proposes the use of two packages developed by him, dplyr and tidyr. The latter may be used to easily "reshape" data, which is one of the most common data manipulations in R.

title: A new data processing workflow for R
description: "Thanks to some great new packages like dplyr, tidyr and magrittr, I've been able to streamline code and speed up processing" says Zev Ross in this very helpful tutorial which processes data from Google's BigQuery. Indeed, just forget functions such as aggregate() or merge() and endless, nested lapply() calls – with the herein presented workflow, everything becomes so much easier and faster. The tutorial ends with some demonstration of ggplot2's capabilities, which you can skip if you're only interested in data manipulation as such.

title: Data wrangling cheat sheet
description: Hadley Wickham's tidyr and the much more feature-rich dplyr are some sort of a declarative mini language within R for data tidying and general data processing – similar to SQL. With this cheat sheet, you'll always know the difference between select() and filter().

title: Do more with dates and times with lubridate
description: At least for me, working with dates and times in R has always been a hassle. For example, I still don't get the actual difference between as.Date(), as.POSIXlt() and as.POSIXct(). lubridate might still require some basic knowledge of date/time types in R, but makes working with, for example, time intervals much more intuitive. Give it a try.

title: Getting started with charts
description: This tutorial is about the base plotting system. It introduces scatterplot matrices, boxplots, and gridded chart displays, among others. In my opinion, you can skip the base plotting system altogether and go straight to ggplot2, but it certainly doesn't hurt to know a bit about it.

title: Data visualization cheat sheet
description: It's the same as with dplyr and tidyr – going with the Hadley-Wickham-Flow makes your life easier. ggplot2 is one of his oldest packages and one of his most used.ggplot2 is based on something called "The Grammar of Graphics" and allows you to construct your plots layer by layer, variable by variable – very intuitive! Nonetheless, it might look a bit complicated at first with its "aesthetics", "geoms", and "coordinate systems", but learning it is worth the effort. The most difficult part, in my opinion, is remembering all the different function calls and their arguments – this cheat sheet will prevent you from going crazy.

title: Beautiful plotting in R: A ggplot2 cheatsheet
description: Another very useful package by Hadley Wickham (who else?) is ggplot2, which facilitates exploratory data analysis (EDA) and plotting by a great deal. Using air pollution data, Zev Ross gives a good introduction into this package, starting with a basic one-line-plot and gradually adding more features and customizations.

title: Cookbook for R (chapter "Graphs")
description: Getting the nitty-gritties of plotting (e.g., axes, labels, legends, etc.) right can be frustrating and tedious, even with ggplot2. This free book chapter has always helped me in looking up quick recipes for special cases – and for everything else, there's StackOverflow.

title: lattice graphics (for scatterplot matrices and heatmaps)
description: If you have a big data set with many variables and want to go super fancy, i.e., dig for correlations among your variables, scatterplot matrices are the way to go. These, using splom() and other cool stuff like heatmaps are available in the lattice package, which is often faster and easier to use with multidimensional data. This tutorial has got you covered (even if you're not into genetics). But remember: correlation != causation.

title: Geting started with Shiny: A web application framework for R
description: Shiny is RStudio's solution for making R plots interactive and publishing them on the web. Shiny apps always consist of a user interface script (ui.R) and a server script (server.R). Shiny apps can be run locally from within RStudio or hosted online. RStudio provides a hosting service on shinyapps.io, but you can also host them on your own, using the free and open source Shiny Server software.

title: rCharts: Interactive Javascript visualizations with familiar libraries
description: This package allows you to create interactive charts in a lattice-style manner from within R. You can choose from a variety of Javascript visualization libraries such as HighCharts, NVD3, or even LeafletJS, all using the same interface. The charts can then be published via a variety of options: As a Gist (see this example), inside a Shiny application (see this example on replicating a NYT graphic), or as a good old HTML file, using knit2html and RMarkdown.

title: htmlwidgets: A package/framework for developing R bindings to Javascript libraries
description: htmlwidgets is rather a framework than a package like rCharts. If you already know Javascript you can use htmlwidgets to create R bindings, so called "widgets", to your favourite library. There already exist a range of bindings. Widgets are built so that they can be used at the R console (a functionality which rCharts lacks, as far as I know) and embedded into RMarkdown (and thus into a plain HTML file) or a Shiny web app. There even exists a blog to promote building widgets, with lots of how-to's.

title: An Introduction on How to Make Beautiful Charts With R and ggplot2
description: In this tutorial blog post, the author describes how to use ggplot2 to create beautiful charts. It focus on how to tweak ggplot2 default layout to get aesthetically improved charts.

title: Writing reproducible reports with markdown, knitr and pandoc
description: Today, making a data journalism project's methodology public is still rather the exception than the rule. If you want to share with your readers what exactly you did with your data, and even allow them to reproduce what you did, R is the ideal setting. Using something called RMarkdown and a package called knitr, you can create nice looking HTML files from your scripts, showing both your (annotated) R code and its output – which can then be published on your website, on a service such as RPubs or on GitHub. This blog post gives a nice introduction in the toolstack needed to perform reproducible data journalism with R. If you only want to know how to create HTML files, you can skip the last part about pandoc.

title: RPubs
description: RPubs, by RStudio, is an ideal service to publish your knitted RMarkdown files – helpful if you only want to publish the markdown, but not your actual code files. From within RStudio, you can easily publish the output HTML file to RPubs.com and then share it with the world. All you need to get started is to create an account on RPubs.com.
